title: How to Make a Simple Mod of a Game

steps.title: Locate the game folder, which is usually in "C:
steps.content: Locate the game folder, which is usually in "C: \Program Files", and find common file types to replace.

steps.title: Use Notepad or another text editor to modify an .ini file (e.g.
steps.content: Use Notepad or another text editor to modify an .ini file (e.g. gunAmmo(26) to gunAmmo(255)). Some .dat * .cfg files can also be modified, but don't try it if you see a bunch of funny symbols

steps.title: Use Paint or another graphics editor to modify image files.
steps.content: Use Paint or another graphics editor to modify image files. These include files with the extensions .bmp (bitmap), .gif (Graphics Interchange Format), .png (portable network graphics), and .jpeg (Joint Photographic Experts Group), among others. Usually these image files are textures to be mapped to certain surfaces or pictures to be used on the game's intro or setup screens.

steps.title: Replace .wav (wave), .mp3 (mpeg3), and .ogg (ogg vorbis) sound and music files with your own.
steps.content: Replace .wav (wave), .mp3 (mpeg3), and .ogg (ogg vorbis) sound and music files with your own. These are audio files that are used for music tracks or sound effects inside a game.
